text: language notes topic 1 titles and forms
of address what do you know about titles
and ways we address people in English
I'm going to write some common forms of
address I want to be sure you can read
them correctly and of course that you
understand them let's start with this
one
mr this is an abbreviation a short form
for mr mr is a title of respect we use
mr before the last name of a man as in
mr. Jackson
good morning mr. Jackson mrs this is an
abbreviation for the word mistress but
we almost always read this as mrs. mrs.
is another title of respect we use this
title before the last name of a married
woman for example mrs. Lebedev mrs.
Jones good afternoon mrs. Jones MS we
pronounce this as ms/ms sounds like a Z
at the end this a woman can choose to
use this title before her last name when
she doesn't wish to indicate whether
she's married or unmarried Ms Jones miss
Davis this title is miss miss with an S
at the end miss we use Miss before the
last name of an unmarried woman listen
miss miss we can also use
alone we can use it as a polite way to
address a young woman whose last name we
don't know a stranger for example excuse
me miss did you drop that mr. and miss
could be used before the first name of a
person when would we do that
well for example my children used mr.
and Miss as titles before the first
names of their teachers when they were
little in day care so they would go to
school and talked to miss Julie miss
Lisa mr. Jack no miss I said could be
used alone as a polite way to address a
stranger but what if the person is a man
then we use sir yes sir
excuse me sir is that yours miss would
be for a younger woman for an older
woman we use ma'am that's short for
madam you say yes ma'am no ma'am may I
help you ma'am let me show you just a
few more because I think you'll come
across them DR have you seen this this
is an abbreviation for doctor we can use
doctor as a title for a person who
practices medicine so a medical doctor a
dentist veterinarian who cares for the
animals doctor can also be used as a
title before the last name of a person
who holds the highest degree from a
college or university if a person
teaches at a college or a university
you'll see this P rof prof
is short for professor doctor and
professor could be used before the
person's last name or alone as a polite
way to address that person excuse me
doctor or excuse me professor I have a
question there's one more title that you
may come across are Evy this is an
abbreviation for the word Reverend if
you see this title it's referring to a
person who is a minister in a Christian
Church and Reverend will be used before
that person's name as in Reverend Jesse
Jackson
you might hear his name in the news
let's review
mr. mrs. MS miss sir ma'am dr. professor
Reverend that's all for this short
lesson thanks for watching and happy
studies
while making this lesson I used these
sources you may find them helpful too
[Music]
please visit my website today at WWE
English with Jennifer calm you'll find
study tips interactive exercises
vocabulary videos and more
